Standard_Text: Discuss how the principles in the Magna Carta were embodied in such documents as the English Bill of Rights and the American Declaration of Independence.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Describe how democratic thought and institutions were influenced by Enlightenment thinkers (e.g., John Locke, Charles-Louis Montesquieu, American founders).
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Explain how the main ideas of the Enlightenment can be traced back to such movements as the Renaissance, the Reformation, and the Scientific Revolution and to the Greeks, Romans, and Christianity.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Examine the origins of modern capitalism; the influence of mercantil­ism and cottage industry; the elements and importance of a market economy in seventeenth-century Europe; the changing international trading and marketing patterns, including their locations on a world map; and the influence of explorers and map makers.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Discuss the exchanges of plants, animals, technology, culture, and ideas among Europe, Africa, Asia, and the Americas in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries and the major economic and social effects on each continent.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Know the great voyages of discovery, the locations of the routes, and the influence of cartography in the development of a new European worldview.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students analyze political and economic change in the sixteenth, seventeenth, and eighteenth centuries (the Age of Exploration, the Enlightenment, and the Age of Reason).
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Understand the scientific method advanced by Bacon and Descartes, the influence of new scientific rationalism on the growth of demo­cratic ideas, and the coexistence of science with traditional religious beliefs.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Understand the significance of the new scientific theories (e.g., those of Copernicus, Galileo, Kepler, Newton) and the significance of new inventions (e.g., the telescope, microscope, thermometer, barometer).
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Discuss the roots of the Scientific Revolution (e.g., Greek rationalism; Jewish, Christian, and Muslim science; Renaissance humanism; new knowledge from global exploration).
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students analyze the historical developments of the Scientific Revolution and its lasting effect on religious, political, and cultural institutions.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Describe the Golden Age of cooperation between Jews and Muslims in medieval Spain that promoted creativity in art, literature, and science, including how that cooperation was terminated by the religious persecution of individuals and groups (e.g., the Spanish Inquisition and the expulsion of Jews and Muslims from Spain in 1492).
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Understand the institution and impact of missionaries on Christianity and the diffusion of Christianity from Europe to other parts of the world in the medieval and early modern periods; locate missions on a world map.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Analyze how the Counter Reformation revitalized the Catholic church and the forces that fostered the movement (e.g., St. Ignatius of Loyola and the Jesuits, the Council of Trent).
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Identify and locate the European regions that remained Catholic and those that became Protestant and explain how the division affected the distribution of religions in the New World.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Explain Protestants' new practices of church self-government and the influence of those practices on the development of democratic practices and ideas of federalism.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Describe the theological, political, and economic ideas of the major figures during the Reformation (e.g., Desiderius Erasmus, Martin Luther, John Calvin, William Tyndale).
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: List the causes for the internal turmoil in and weakening of the Catholic church (e.g., tax policies, selling of indulgences).
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students analyze the historical developments of the Reformation.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Detail advances made in literature, the arts, science, mathematics, cartography, engineering, and the understanding of human anatomy and astronomy (e.g., by Dante Alighieri, Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo di Buonarroti Simoni, Johann Gutenberg, William Shakespeare).
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Describe the growth and effects of new ways of disseminating infor­mation (e.g., the ability to manufacture paper, translation of the Bible into the vernacular, printing).
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Understand the effects of the reopening of the ancient "Silk Road" between Europe and China, including Marco Polo's travels and the location of his routes.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Explain the importance of Florence in the early stages of the Renais­sance and the growth of independent trading cities (e.g., Venice), with emphasis on the cities' importance in the spread of Renaissance ideas.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Describe the way in which the revival of classical learning and the arts fostered a new interest in humanism (i.e., a balance between intellect and religious faith).
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students analyze the origins, accomplishments, and geographic diffusion of the Renaissance.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Describe the Meso-American achievements in astronomy and mathematics, including the development of the calendar and the Meso-American knowledge of seasonal changes to the civilizations' agricultural systems.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Describe the artistic and oral traditions and architecture in the three civilizations.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Explain how and where each empire arose and how the Aztec and Incan empires were defeated by the Spanish.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Study the roles of people in each society, including class structures, family life, warfare, religious beliefs and practices, and slavery.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Study the locations, landforms, and climates of Mexico, Central America, and South America and their effects on Mayan, Aztec, and Incan economies, trade, and development of urban societies.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students compare and contrast the geographic, political, economic, religious, and social structures of the Meso-American and Andean civilizations.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Know the history of the decline of Muslim rule in the Iberian Penin-Grade Seven sula that culminated in the Reconquista and the rise of Spanish Portuguese kingdoms.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Understand the importance of the Catholic church as a political, intellectual, and aesthetic institution (e.g., founding of universities, political and spiritual roles of the clergy, creation of monastic and mendicant religious orders, preservation of the Latin language and religious texts, St. Thomas Aquinas's synthesis of classical philosophy with Christian theology, and the concept of "natural law").
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Map the spread of the bubonic plague from Central Asia to China, the Middle East, and Europe and describe its impact on global population.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Discuss the causes and course of the religious Crusades and their effects on the Christian, Muslim, and Jewish populations in Europe, with emphasis on the increasing contact by Europeans with cultures of the Eastern Mediterranean world.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Know the significance of developments in medieval English legal and constitutional practices and their importance in the rise of modern democratic thought and representative institutions (e.g., Magna Carta, parliament, development of habeas corpus, an independent judiciary in England).
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Demonstrate an understanding of the conflict and cooperation between the Papacy and European monarchs (e.g., Charlemagne, Gregory VII, Emperor Henry IV).
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Understand the development of feudalism, its role in the medieval European economy, the way in which it was influenced by physical geography (the role of the manor and the growth of towns), and how feudal relationships provided the foundation of political order.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Describe the spread of Christianity north of the Alps and the roles played by the early church and by monasteries in its diffusion after the fall of the western half of the Roman Empire.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Study the geography of Europe and the Eurasian land mass, including their location, topography, waterways, vegetation, and climate and their relationship to ways of life in Medieval Europe.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students analyze the geographic, political, economic, religious, and social structures of the civilizations of Medieval Europe.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Analyze the rise of a military society in the late twelfth century and the role of the samurai in that society.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Study the ninth and tenth centuries' golden age of literature, art, and drama and its lasting effects on culture today, including Murasaki Shikibu's Tale of Genji.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Trace the development of distinctive forms of Japanese Buddhism.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Describe the values, social customs, and traditions prescribed by the Content lord-vassal system consisting of shogun, daimyo, and samurai and lasting influence of the warrior code throughout the twentieth century.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Discuss the reign of Prince Shotoku of Japan and the characteristics of Japanese society and family life during his reign.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Describe the significance of Japan's proximity to China and Korea and the intellectual, linguistic, religious, and philosophical influence of those countries on Japan.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students analyze the geographic, political, economic, religious, and social structures of the civilizations of Medieval Japan.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Describe the importance of written and oral traditions in the trans-mission of African history and culture.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Trace the growth of the Arabic language in government, trade, and Islamic scholarship in West Africa.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Describe the role of the trans-Saharan caravan trade in the changing religious and cultural characteristics of West Africa and the influence of Islamic beliefs, ethics, and law.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Analyze the importance of family, labor specialization, and regional commerce in the development of states and cities in West Africa.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Study the Niger River and the relationship of vegetation zones of forest, savannah, and desert to trade in gold, salt, food, and slaves; and the growth of the Ghana and Mali empires.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students analyze the geographic, political, economic, religious, and social structures of the sub-Saharan civilizations of Ghana and Mali in Medieval Africa.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Describe the development of the imperial state and the scholar-official class.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Trace the historic influence of such discoveries as tea, the manufac­ture of paper, wood-block printing, the compass, and gunpowder.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Understand the importance of both overland trade and maritime expeditions between China and other civilizations in the Mongol Ascendancy and Ming Dynasty.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Analyze the influences of Confucianism and changes in Confucian thought during the Song and Mongol periods.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Describe agricultural, technological, and commercial developments during the Tang and Song periods.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Describe the reunification of China under the Tang Dynasty and reasons for the spread of Buddhism in Tang China, Korea, and Japan.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students analyze the geographic, political, economic, religious, and social structures of the civilizations of China in the Middle Ages.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Understand the intellectual exchanges among Muslim scholars of Eurasia and Africa and the contributions Muslim scholars made to later civilizations in the areas of science, geography, mathematics, philosophy, medicine, art, and literature.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Describe the growth of cities and the establishment of trade routes among Asia, Africa, and Europe, the products and inventions that traveled along these routes (e.g., spices, textiles, paper, steel, new crops), and the role of merchants in Arab society.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Discuss the expansion of Muslim rule through military conquests and treaties, emphasizing the cultural blending within Muslim civilization and the spread and acceptance of Islam and the Arabic language.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Explain the significance of the Qur'an and the Sunnah as the primary sources of Islamic beliefs, practice, and law, and their influence in Muslims' daily life.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Trace the origins of Islam and the life and teachings of Muhammad, including Islamic teachings on the connection with Judaism and Christianity.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Identify the physical features and describe the climate of the Arabian peninsula, its relationship to surrounding bodies of land and water, and nomadic and sedentary ways of life.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students analyze the geographic, political, economic, religious, and social structures of the civilizations of Islam in the Middle Ages.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Describe the establishment by Constantine of the new capital in Constantinople and the development of the Byzantine Empire, with an emphasis on the consequences of the development of two distinct European civilizations, Eastern Orthodox and Roman Catholic, and their two distinct views on church-state relations.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Discuss the geographic borders of the empire at its height and the factors that threatened its territorial cohesion.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Study the early strengths and lasting contributions of Rome (e.g., significance of Roman citizenship; rights under Roman law; Roman art, architecture, engineering, and philosophy; preservation and transmission of Christianity) and its ultimate internal weaknesses (e.g., rise of autonomous military powers within the empire, under-mining of citizenship by the growth of corruption and slavery, lack of education, and distribution of news).
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students analyze the causes and effects of the vast expansion and ultimate disintegration of the Roman Empire.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: World History and Geography: Medieval and Early Modern Times
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students interpret basic indicators of economic performance and conduct cost-benefit analyses of economic and political issues.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students recognize that interpretations of history are subject to change as new information is uncovered.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students recognize the role of chance, oversight, and error in history.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students explain the sources of historical continuity and how the combination of ideas and events explains the emergence of new patterns.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students understand and distinguish cause, effect, sequence, and correlation in historical events, including the long-and short-term causal relations.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students explain the central issues and problems from the past, placing people and events in a matrix of time and place.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Historical Interpretation
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students detect the different historical points of view on historical events and determine the context in which the historical statements were made (the questions asked, sources used, author's perspectives).
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students assess the credibility of primary and secondary sources and draw sound conclusions from them.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students distinguish relevant from irrelevant information, essential from incidental information, and verifiable from unverifiable information in historical narratives and stories.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students distinguish fact from opinion in historical narratives and stories.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students frame questions that can be answered by historical study and research.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Research, Evidence, and Point of View
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students use a variety of maps and documents to identify physical and cultural features of neighborhoods, cities, states, and countries and to explain the historical migration of people, expansion and disintegration of empires, and the growth of economic systems.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students construct various time lines of key events, people, and periods of the historical era they are studying.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Students explain how major events are related to one another in time.
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Chronological and Spatial Thinking
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Historical and Social Sciences Analysis Skills
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: The Impact of Ideas, 1500–1750
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Global Convergence, 1450–1750
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Sites of Encounter in Medieval World, 1150–1490
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: West Africa, 900–1400
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: The Americas, 300–1490
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: East Asia, 300–1300: China and Japan
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: South Asia, 300–1200
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Southwestern Asia, 300–1200: Persia and the World of Islam
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: Rome and Christendom, 300 CE–1200
Subject: History-Social Science

Standard_Text: The World in 300 CE
Subject: History-Social Science
